titleStmt.title: To Sir William Davenant: Upon the Unspeakable Loss of the Most Conspicuous and Chief Ornament of His Frontispiece
Poem #60

encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: PG#To S:r W:m D: Upon the unſpeakable Loſs of the most conspicious and chief Ornament of his &ff;rontispiece

rdg.seg: To Sir William Davenant: Upon the Unspeakable Loss of the Most Conspicuous and Chief Ornament of His FrontispieceWilliam Davenant (1606-1668) was a famous English playwright who served as poet laureate and was knighted by Charles I. In 1630, he contracted syphilis and took mercury as a cure, which disfigured his nose. An “ornament” is an accessory; a “frontispiece” is a face but also the front of a building, the engraved panel over an entrance, or the first page or title page of a book.

app.rdg: AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

app.rdg: Sir,
Extreamly I deplore your loſs
Extremely I deplorelament your loss:
You’r like Cheapſide without a Croſs“r” written over another letter

You’re like Cheapside without a crossCheapside was a location in London which had a stone carved cross erected on it to memorialize the funeral procession of King Edward I’s wife; the cross was destroyed in 1643 by an act of Parliament targeting “monuments of superstition and idolatry.”,
Or like A Diall Gnoman and noein H2; “and noe” directly above cancelled “Gnoman,” struck-through twice Gnoman
Or like a dial and no gnomonA pin or rod that indicates the time of day by casting its shadow upon the surface of a sundial: a dial without the rod is useless.;
In pitty (trust mee) I think noe man
In pity (trust me) I think no man
But would his Leg or Arm expoſe
But would his leg or arm expose
To cut you out another Noſe
To cut you out another nose;
Nor of the &ff;emale Sex thers none
Nor of the female sex there’s none
But’ld bee one &ff;leſh though not one Bone

But’ldBut would be one flesh, though not one bonewould marry him even if not agreeing to offer up their bones. On marriage as becoming “one flesh,” see Genesis 2:23-24: “And Adam said, this is now bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh: she shall be called woman, because she was taken out of man. “Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife: and they shall be one flesh.”.
I though unknown would Sleight the pain
I, though unknown, would slightdisregard the pain
That you might haue Soe great a gain
That you might have so great a gain.
Nay Any &ff;ool did hee know itt
Nay, any fool, did he know it,
Would give his Noſe to have yo:r Wit
Would give his nose to have your wit,
And I my Self would doe the Same
And I myself would do the same,
Did I not fear t’wold Blur my &ff;ame
Did I not fear ’twould blur my fameThe loss of a nose could be a sign of syphilis or criminal punishment, thus hurting one’s reputation..
I as once Said a Gallant Dame
I, as once said a gallantrefined, noble dame,
My Noſe would venture not my &ff;ame
My nose would venturerisk, not my fame;
&ff;or who but that Bright eye above
For who but that bright eyethe sun, symbol of God above
Would know twere Charity not Love
Would know ’twere charity, not love.
Then S:r your Pardon I must Beg
Then, sir, your pardon I must beg;
Excuſe my Noſe accept my Leg
Excuse my nose, accept my legThe speaker will allow a skin graft from her leg, or she is offering to curtsy as she asks for pardon..
But yet beſure bot night and Day
But yet, be sure both night and day
&ff;or mee as for your Self you pray
For me, as for yourself, you pray;
&ff;or if I &ff;irst should chance to goe
For if I first should chance to go
To viſit thoſe Sad Shades below
To visit those sad shadesthe netherworld or people in it below,
As my &ff;rail &ff;leſh there putrifies
As my frail flesh there putrefies,
Your Noſe noe doubt will Sympathize
Your nose, no doubt, will sympathize.
But this I fear least that blind Boy
But this I fear: lest that blind boyCupid
Which &ff;ate deſcend (Yet such a Toy
Which fate descendssends down (yet such a toytrivial thing
May take the Chit) Should Shoot again
May take the chitbratty child) should shoot again,
Then the Next loſs would bee yo:r Brain

rdg.seg: Then the next loss would be your brain.perhaps suggesting that Cupid (the “chit”) might not be able to resist Davenant, particularly his brain (the shiny “toy”) but “yet” (still) “take” it (shoot again), with the result that Davenant would lose his brain.

app.rdg: Some Coy Young Laſs you Might Adore
Some coy young lass you might adore,
Which would prefer Some baſe Medore

Which would prefer some base MedoreMedoro is a non-noble Moor (or Muslim) in Ludovico Ariosto’s 1532 poem, Orlando Furioso, with whom Angelica (a Chinese princess at the court of Charlemagne) falls in love (thus rejecting the title character Orlando).,
And all your Witt and Titles Sleight
And all your wit and titles slight:
Imbrace a Page before a Knight
Embrace a page before a knight.
Then Should Some Nobleminded &ff;reind
Then should some noble-minded friend,
Astolpho like to Heaven aſcend“c” appears added later, in darker ink

Astolfo-likeAstolpho is a character in Ariosto’s Orlando Furioso who flies in a flaming chariot to the moon where all things that have been lost on Earth are stored in jars. Here he recovers the wits that the title character Orlando had lost when rejected by his beloved. Astolfo makes Orlando snort his wits back up his nose., to heaven ascend,
And having Search’d neare and &ff;arr
And having searchéd near and far
And found your most capacious Jarr
And found your most capacious jar,
Then beeing with Joy Returnd again
Then being, with joy, returned again
You could not then Snuf up your Brain
You could not then snuff up your brain:
Though all your Strenght you Should expoſe
Though all your strength you should expose
You want the Organe cal’d a Noſe
You want the organ called a nose.
Prodigious the Knight Remains
Prodigiouswondrous, the knight remains
Withous or Noſe, or &ff;ame or Brains,
Without oreither nose, or fame, or brains.
Then I bold ordinance Strook the Title of

Then a bold ordinanceEardley speculates that this alludes to “An Ordinance Concerning the Peers of Parliament, and other Honors and Titles” (1646), which prevented peers created since 1642 from sitting in Parliament and voided their titles. Charles I had made Davenant a knight in 1643. struck the title off;
Thus the proud Parces Sit and at us Scofe
Thus the proud Parcaethe three female Fates sit, and at us scoff.
What now remains the Man at Least
What now remains? The man at least?
Noe Surely nothing left but Beast
No, surely nothing left but beast.
Then Royall &ff;avour glu’d it on again
Then royal favor glued it on again,
And now the K:t“K” appears to correct earlier “R” is Bow-di’de and in grain

And now the knight is bow-dyed and ingrain“bow-dyed” is dyed scarlet (named for the Bow Bridge in proximity to the workplace of dyers); the state of being “ingrain,” or “ingrained,” is to have caused a dye to sink into the texture of a fabric and thus be indelible. These lines refer to King Charles’s knighting of Davenant in 1643, which restores the honor he lost when his nose was disfigured..
Then Trample not that Hono:r in ye Dust
Then trample not that honor in the dust
In beeing a Slave to thoſe are Slaves to Lust

rdg.seg: In being a slave to those are slaves to lust.“those” is ambiguous, but generally signifies temptations.
